...and this is the critical (although subtle) mistake. Why? Because of the pawns on d4, e5, and f4. After the exchanges that follow, White takes c6 and Black is forced to trap one rook on the back rank defending the pawn on e6 - because with the c- and e-pawns out of the way, White has an excellent shot at promoting their own d- and/or e-pawn, effectively ending the game. Better is 18...Rc8.
Black neglects to guard e6. They still have one chance to salvage this: 22...Rb6.
